Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend who has just started assembling furniture asks for a quick video call because the instructions are confusing.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story: My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the curb, two travelers waving at me, their arms full of suitcases. I glanced at the screen—my friend’s name flashed with a desperate message: “Can you video call? I’m stuck with this bookshelf and the instructions make no sense.” I could almost hear the frustration in her voice. As a friend, I knew she counted on me, especially since she’d just moved and didn’t know many people in town. But as a taxi driver, I had two customers waiting, expecting me to help load their heavy bags and get them to the airport on time. They looked impatient, glancing at their watches, and I could feel their expectation for quick, professional service. My heart pounded as I weighed the urgency in my friend’s text against the responsibility to my passengers. I felt torn, guilt creeping in no matter which way I leaned. I gripped the steering wheel, caught between the pull of friendship and the demands of my job, unsure which role I could afford to let down.
